results.title: Hotel New York
results.brief_description: This is the final version of “New York” shown by Jackie Raynal in 1980 as a work-in-progress. It is the story of Loulou Blanchot, a French filmmaker who decides to live in New York after having been invited to show one of her films there. Loulou begins to get acquainted with the city and gets a job as an editor for a porno film company.

results.title: Hotel du Nord
results.brief_description:
In a cheap hotel near the canal St Martin, two star crossed lovers, Pierre and Renee, rent a room to execute their suicide pact. Pierre shoots Renee but lacks the courage to kill himself and runs away. Renee survives her ordeal and is adopted by the small community surrounding the hotel. She becomes a good friend of Monsieur Edmond, gangster and occasional pimp to Raymonde. Edmond falls in love with Renee and offers to run away with her to the Colonies. ‘Hotel du Nord’ is the second film in Carne’s trilogy of ‘poetic realist’ films, including ‘Quai des Brumes’ and ‘Le Jour se Leve’. In August 1939, on the eve of WWII, the French Ministry of Information drew up a list of 51 “depressing, morbid, immoral and bad for the youths” films, including ‘Hotel du Nord’. In the Carne canon, ‘Hotel du Nord’ is usually eclipsed by ‘Le Quai des Brumes’, ‘Le jour se leve’ (1939) and ‘Les Enfants du Paradis’ (1945), largely because of Prevert’s absence. Jeanson’s dialogue is indeed broader, the film more comic. In this respect, ‘Hotel du Nord’ is ‘theatrical realism’ rather than ‘poetic realism’. But in the interaction of set, camerawork and Maurice Jaubert’s restrained, moody music, ‘Hotel du Nord’ is typical of poetic realism. Its poetry is embodied in the superb set designed by Alexandre Trauner, a replica of one side of the Canal Saint-Martin, complete with bridges, punctuated by location shots of the canal and barges. The set is plainly artificial, yet still a microcosm of Paris which we enter with the young couple, the camera following them down the side of the bridge. (A reverse of this movement takes us out at the end of the film.) Graham Greene, who loved French cinema for knowing ‘the immense importance of the careful accessory’, once wrote, “in Hotel du Nord we believe in desperate lovers and the suicide pact on the brass bed in the shabby room, just because of the bicyclists on the quay, the pimp quarrelling with his woman in another room, and the First Communion party.” Social events such as strikes are a faint echo, as is the international situation (a young Spanish refugee is marginal to the story). Carne was more daring on the gender front. Characters may take the hackneyed appearance of pimps and prostitutes, but they are free of conventional morality. Edmond and Renee’s brief interlude is clearly sexual. When it is over (and although Edmond is smitten), they both shrug it off without guilt. Adrien is (for the time) a rare sympathetic portrayal of a gay character.” Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. ‘Hotel du Nord’. Sight and Sound, March 1999: p. 41-42. =Held in our collection.

Credits: Director, Marcel Carne ; writers, Henri Jeanson, Jean Aurenche ; photography, Armand Thirard ; music, Maurice Jaubert ; art direction, Alexandre Trauner.
Cast: Louis Jouvet, Arletty, Annabella, Jean-Pierre Aumont, Bernard Blier, Andrex, Paulette Dubost, Jane Marken, Francois Perier, Andre Brunot.

results.title: Hotel du Lac
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Sue Birtwistle and Giles Foster
results.brief_description: After narrowly avoiding an unsuitable marriage, a woman novelist retreats to an elegant Swiss hotel in the off-season, where she ponders her life whilst carefully observing her fellow guests. A nicely paced and detailed adaptation of a Booker Prize-winning novel, by Anita Brookner, filmed amidst the lakes and mountains of Switzerland. Stars Anna Massey and Denholm Elliott.

results.title: Hotel de Love
results.creator_credit: Pratt Film Productions, Michael Lake, David Parker and Craig Rosenburg
results.brief_description: Teenagers, smooth-talking party animal, Rick (Aden Young) and his shy twin brother Stephen (Simon Bossell) fall for the same gorgeous uni student, Melissa (Saffron Burrows). Rick woos her and then loses her. A decade on and Rick is working as the manager of Hotel de Love, a tacky, neon-laced romantic hideaway, whilst Stephen has buried himself in the world of stockbroking. Life is dull and unchallenging until Melissa arrives at the hotel and the hijinks begin. Also starring Pippa Grandison, Ray Barrett and Julia Blake.

results.title: Hotel colonial (D)
results.creator_credit: Hemdale Film Corporation, Legeis Theatrical, Ira Barmak and Cinzia Th Torrini
results.brief_description: Early one morning, Marco (John Savage), an Italo-American living in America, is awoken by a phone call delivering the news of his brother’s death, Luca, a shady character involved in the Italian mafia and terrorism. Marco heads to Bogota, Columbia, where his brother allegedly committed suicide, in order to identify the body and bring him home. However, all is not what it seems when Marco discovers the body is not his brother’s and the suicide may be a murder. Marco is determined to find his brother, and based on a few clues that point him to a small village in remote Columbia, and knowledge of his brothers’ various aliases and his involvement in drug trafficking, he begins the journey of unravelling the truth. Throughout the search, Marco meets a few characters, becomes acquainted with the locals and learns to appreciate the innocence, natural beauty though indisputable poverty of this small Columbian village. However, upon closer inspection of his environment, Marco also sees the evil, corruption and exploitation that transpire in this small village. It’s only in the depths of this dark and uncivilised land that Marco confronts the true and shocking reality of his brother’s whereabouts, and that he learns its corruption is inseparable from the activities of his own flesh and blood. Despite its cliched plot scenarios and mediocre performances, “Hotel Colonial” shows some genuine concern for the plight of South American peoples though from the perspective of a white American male. Cast also includes Robert Duvall and Rachel Ward. SOME SCENES MAY DISTURB.

results.title: Hot wheels
results.creator_credit: McBrearty Film Productions, ONF | NFB, Beryl Fox and Don McBrearty
results.brief_description: A story where two girls turn down two boys for more prosperous dates. In anger, the teenage boys steal a car and after a drinking session accidentally meet up with the girls. The drivers of the two cars challenge each other to a race. A fictional film, dramatising a situation where pride, alcohol and wheels combine with disastrous results.

results.title: Hot water; Safety last
results.creator_credit: Time-Life Films, Bob Hoag and Fred C Newmeyer
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “New Versions of Comedy Classics”
This film is a new print of two old comedy films. ‘Hot Water’, made in 1924, is about Harold taking a live turkey on a trolley ride and then taking his in-laws for an equally hysterical ride in his new car. Also stars Jobyna Ralston, Josephine Crowell, Charles A. Stevenson and Mickey McBan. Written by Tommy Gray and John Grey. The second film, called ‘Safety Last’, was made in 1923 and is about Harold going to the big city to make his fortune and includes the scene “Harold Lloyd on the clock”. Also stars Mildred Davis and Bill Strothers. Written by Jean C. Havez and Sam Taylor.

results.title: Hot stuff. The Ride. Dinosaur. Rip Van Winkle
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Will Vinton Productions, Billy Budd Films, Colin Low, Will Vinton, Zlatko Grgic and Gerald Potterton
results.brief_description: A compilation of four excellent short films; two from The National Film Board of Canada and two from Will Vinton who pioneered clay animation. “Hot Stuff” (Canada, 1972, 10 min.): An award winning animated film about fire as the servant of man. “The Ride” (Canada, 1963, 7 min.): A slapstick comedy about a chauffeur for an eccentric tycoon chasing a runaway sled. “Dinosaur” (U.S., 1980, 14 min.): A clay animated interpretation of how earth existed before man. “Rip Van Winkle” (U.S., 1979, 29 min.) An adaptation of Washington Irving’s classic tale of a man who would rather tell stories than work in the fields.

results.title: Hot stuff
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Wolf Koenig, Robert Verrall and Zlatko Grgic
results.brief_description: This film traces man’s carelessness with fire, from its discovery to present day. Early man is warned that he must keep fire under control, but he gradually ignores this waring. Over-loaded sockets, smouldering cigarettes and other fire hazards result in the destruction of life and property. Story by Don Arioli. (Awards include: Melbourne, Toronto, New York, Atlanta, Zagreb, Chicago, Oberhausen.) Also available on DVD [319319].

results.title: Hot shots! (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Peter Miller Investment Corp, Bill Badalato and Jim Abrahams
results.brief_description: A spoof of “Top Gun” in which Charlie Sheen stars as Topeer Harley, an ace fighter pilot who’s recruited to join a team of crack (or is it cracked?) jet jockeys for a top-secret mission Led by their incompetent commander (Lloyd Bridges). The squadron includes a half-blind pilot named ‘Wash-Out’ and a vain and smug golden boy. Together they train for operation ‘Sleepy Weasle’, a lightning strike against a desert kingdom. Meanwhile they spend their nights carousing in a nightclub where the beautiful airbase psychiatrist moonlights as a sexy chanteuse. To round out the insanity, a devious contractor is out to sabotage their mission.
